    <h1><span id="ctl00_mainContent_Label1">Announcements</span></h1>    
	<div id="announcementsX">
    <div id="ctl00_mainContent_ContentBlock1">
	<ul>    <li><strong>                      The ASBMB's Interactive Mentoring Activities for Grantsmanship Enhancement (IMAGE) grant-writing workshop is for assistant professors and postdocs who are transitioning into independent faculty positions. The deadline to apply is <span style="color: rgb(210, 35, 42);">April 13</span>. <a href="http://www.asbmb.org/grantwriting/" title="Learn more">Learn more</a>       <br/> </strong> </li>    <li><strong>Looking for your next job? Visit the <a href="http://www.asbmb.org/Careers/JobBoard/">ASBMB Job Board</a> for recent postings of academic and industry positions from around the world. <br/></strong>        <br/>    </li>    <li><b><a href="http://www.asbmb.org/awards/" title="Nominate a colleague">Nominate a colleague</a> for an ASBMB annual award. The deadline for nominations is <strong><span style="color: rgb(210, 35, 42);">May 2</span></strong>.</b><span></span><strong><br/></strong> </li></ul>
</div>
	</div>
     
      
   <br/>
     	 <h1><a href="/NewsByCategory.aspx" style="text-decoration:none"> ASBMB News</a> </h1>    
    <span id="ctl00_mainContent_ListSummary1"><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=76411">Apply for the IMAGE grant-writing workshop</a><Teaser><p>The
ASBMB's IMAGE grant-writing workshop is for assistant professors and postdocs
who are transitioning into independent faculty positions. Participants will
receive individualized feedback on their research proposals and post-workshop
mentoring. Applicants from underrepresented backgrounds, postdocs and faculty
m</p></Teaser></div><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=76294">ASBMB Today March 2018</a><Teaser><p>  This month, we look at myalgic encephalomyelitis, aka chronic fatigue syndrome; the NIH recently announced $7 million in designated funding, but advocates say that’s nowhere near enough. JBC associate editor Ursula Jakob discusses her work with bacterial bleach. And we introduce the 2018 JBC/Herbert Tabor Young Investigator Award winners.   </p></Teaser></div></span>
        <!--64/live-70 -->
	<br/> 
     <h1><a href="/NewsByCategory.aspx?catId=186&path=%5cNews%5cJournal+News&__taxonomyshowall=1" style="text-decoration:none">Journal News</a></h1>
       <span id="ctl00_mainContent_ListSummary11"><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=76069">The Year in JBC</a><Teaser><p> Look back on 2017 with The Year in JBC, a special collection of papers across the journal's subject areas. And catch up on review papers you may have missed with the  2017 Minireview Compendium . Both of the collections are free to download. Share them with your peers and students. </p></Teaser></div><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=75903">Your technological advances belong at MCP</a><Teaser><p>  Molecular &amp; Cellular Proteomics  is the home
for papers describing new, impactful technologies that make substantial
contributions to the understanding of proteomics. As described in the
editors'    January editorial, papers describing
these technologies do not have to include solutions to biological
problems. The editors encourage authors to submit technology papers to
MCP.  
  </p></Teaser></div></span>
<br/>


     <h1><a href="/NewsByCategory.aspx?catId=140&path=%5cNews%5cMember+News&__taxonomyshowall=1" style="text-decoration:none">Member News</a></h1>

	  <span id="ctl00_mainContent_ListSummary21"><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=76303">Jakob joins JBC as associate editor</a><Teaser><p>Ursula Jakob of the University of Michigan became an associate editor for the Journal of Biological Chemistry in September. She spoke with ASBMB Today about her lab’s work exploring molecular chaperones and mechanisms of bleach resistance in bacterial and human cells. </p></Teaser></div><div class="newsHome"><a class="title" href="/News.aspx?id=76301">Cech named science adviser to STORM Therapeutics</a><Teaser><p>STORM Therapeutics has named Thomas Cech as a science adviser.

Founded in 2015, STORM Therapeutics is a British-based developer of small-molecule inhibitors of RNA-modifying enzymes for the treatment of cancer.

A leading figure in the field of RNA research, Cech shared the 1989 Nobel Prize in chemistry for discovering the catalytic properties of RNA.</p></Teaser></div></span>
